column7: also transliterated as T'amar or Thamar; c. 1160 – 18 January 1213) in the newly unified Kingdom of Georgia. During the Queen's rule
column8: sizeable groups of immigrating Georgians moved to Trabzon where they continue to preserve their native tongue. There was an Armenian community in Trebizond as early as the 7th century.During the 13th and 14th centuries
column9: numerous Armenian families migrated there from Ani. Robert W. Edwards published part of an early 15th-century diary from the Castilian ambassador who visited Trabzon and compared the churches of the Greek and Armenian communities.  It was stated by the ambassador that the Armenians
column10: who were not well-liked by the Greeks
column11: had a population large enough to support a resident bishop.  According to Ronald C. Jennings
column13: Armenians made up approximately 13 percent of the city's population. At present
column14: Trabzon does not have an Armenian-speaking community.

column1: The Chepni people
column2: a tribe of Oghuz Turks who played an important role in the history of the eastern Black Sea area in the 13th and 14th centuries
column3: live in the Şalpazarı (Ağasar valley) region of the Trabzon Province. Very little has been written on the Turkification of the area. There are no historical records of any considerable Turkish-speaking groups in the Trabzon area until the late 15th century
column4: with the exception of the Chepnis. The original Greek (and in some regions Armenian) speakers imposed features from their mother language into the Turkish spoken in the region. Heath W. Lowry's work with Halil İnalcık on Ottoman tax books (Tahrir Defteri) provides detailed demographic statistics for the city of Trabzon and its surrounding areas during the Ottoman period.

column1: It is possible that the majority of the population of Trabzon and Rize (and other ancient Greek colonies in the Pontus region) — except up to the time of the Chepni Turk immigration waves — consisted of indigenous Caucasian tribes (the Colchians and the Laz) who had been partly Hellenized religiously and linguistically. Michael Meeker stresses the cultural resemblances (e.g. in village structure
column2: house types
column3: and pastoral techniques) between the Eastern Black Sea coast and the areas in the Caucasus proper.

column1: == Main sights ==
Trabzon has a number of tourist attractions
column2: some of them dating back to the times of the ancient empires that once existed in the region. In the city itself
column3: one can find a hub of shops
column4: stalls and restaurants surrounding the Meydan
column5: a square in the center of the city
column6: which includes a tea garden.

column1: The Hagia Sophia (Turkish: Ayasofya Müzesi)
column2: a stunning Byzantine church
column3: is probably the town's most important tourist attraction.

column1: Trabzon Castle ruins are visible in the town but cannot be visited as they fall in a military zone.  The outside wall of the castle now serves as the back wall of a military building.

The "Atatürk Köşkü" is a villa built in 1890 by a local Greek merchant. In 1924 Mustafa Kemal Atatürk stayed in the villa during his visit to Trabzon. He stayed there again in 1937. It houses period rooms and serves as a monument to the memory of the founder and first President of the Republic of Turkey.

Boztepe Park is a small park and tea garden on the hills above Trabzon that has a panoramic view of nearly the entire city. The terrain in Trabzon is ascending in such a way that although the view is far above that of the buildings below
column2: it is still close enough to be able to observe the flow of traffic and the people moving about in the city.

column1: == Culture ==
Folk dancing is still very much in evidence in the Black Sea region. The "Horon" is a famous dance that is indigenous to the city and its surrounding area. It is performed by men
column2: women
column3: the young and elderly alike; in festivities
column4: local weddings and harvest times. While similar to Russian Cossack dances in terms of vividness
column5: the Trabzon folk dance is probably indigenous to the eastern Black Sea region
column6: which has an impressive variety of folk music.

column1: The people of Trabzon have a reputation for being religiously conservative and nationalist. Many Trabzonites generally show a strong sense of loyalty to their family
column2: friends
column3: religion and country. Atatürk selected his presidential guards from Trabzon and the neighbouring city of Giresun because of their fierce fighting ability and their loyalty.

column1: Outside of the relatively urban space of Trabzon proper
column2: and within parts of it as well
column3: rural traditions from the Black Sea village life are still thriving. These include traditional gender roles
column4: social conservatism
column5: hospitality and a willingness to help strangers; and all aspects
column6: both positive and negative
column7: of an agrarian lifestyle
column8: such as hard work

column1: The people of the eastern Black Sea region are also known for their wit and sense of humour; many jokes in Turkey are told about the natives of the Black Sea region Karadeniz fıkraları (Black Sea jokes). The character Temel
column2: a universal buffoon figure found in many cultures
column3: forms an important part of the Turkish oral tradition.

column1: The city's profile was raised somewhat in the English-speaking world by Dame Rose Macaulay's last novel
column2: The Towers of Trebizond (1956)
column3: which is still in print.

column1: == Education ==
Black Sea Technical University in Trabzon hosts students from all over Turkey
column2: especially from the Black Sea and East Anatolian regions
column3: as well as students from the Turkic states in Central Asia.

column1: Historically the city was a center of Greek culture and education and from 1683 to 1921
column2: a teachers' college operated known as Phrontisterion of Trapezous
column3: which provided a major impetus for the rapid expansion of Greek education throughout the region. The building of this institution (built in 1902) still remains the most impressive Pontic Greek monument in the city and today hosts the Turkish school Anadolu Lisesi.

column1: == Cuisine ==
Trabzon's regional cuisine is traditionally reliant on fish
column2: especially hamsi (fresh European Anchovy similar to the British Sprat or American Smelt). Trabzon meets 20% of the total fish production in Turkey. Regional dishes include the Akçaabat köfte (spicy lamb meatball from the Akçaabat district)
column3: Karadeniz pidesi (canoe shaped pita bread
column4: often filled with ground beef
column5: cheese and eggs)
column6: kuymak (a Turkish fondue made with cornmeal
column7: fresh butter and cheese)
column8: Vakfıkebir ekmeği (large country-style bread)
column10: tava mısır ekmeği (deep-dish corn bread) and kara lahana çorbası (bean and cabbage soup). Taflan kavurması is a cherry laurel dish served with onions and olive oil. Trabzon is also famous for its hazelnuts. The Black Sea region of Turkey is the world's largest producer of cherry and hazelnut; and a large production area of tea; all of which play an important role in the local cuisine.

column1: == Sports ==
Football is the most popular sport in Trabzon. The city's top sports club
column2: Trabzonspor
column3: was until 2010 the only Turkish football club outside İstanbul to win the Süper Lig (six times)
column4: which was previously (until Trabzonspor's first championship title in the 1975–76 season) won only by the "Big Three" clubs of Istanbul
column5: namely Galatasaray
column6: Fenerbahçe and Beşiktaş. Due to Trabzonspor's success
column7: the decades-old term "Big Three" which defined the most successful football clubs in Turkey had to be modified into the "Big Four".

column1: Trabzonspor is also one of the most successful Turkish clubs in the European Cups
column2: managing to beat numerous prominent teams such as Barcelona
column3: Inter
column4: Liverpool
column5: Aston Villa and Olympique Lyonnais. Renowned former players of Trabzonspor include Şenol Güneş
column6: Lars Olsen and Shota Arveladze.
